data.text: Contents
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees) .................................... 5
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust .................................... 5
Purpose

The Mid and South Essex University Hospitals (MSE) Group recognises the importance of reliable information as a fundamental requirement for the speedy and effective treatment of patients. Data quality is crucial and the availability of complete, accurate and timely data is important in supporting patient care, clinical governance, management and service agreements for healthcare planning and accountability.

In order to support both the delivery of patient care and its core business, it is the policy of this Group to ensure all patient related information meets nationally identified standards and complies with national legislation.

Increasing emphasis will be placed on the provision and use of good quality data in order to be able to demonstrate achievement of the Groups goals through its business objectives. This policy must be followed by all staff that collect record or process data on behalf of the Group. The full scope of patient, service and corporate related information recorded in the Group is covered by this policy, whether it is paper based, electronic or held on any other media format.
Definitions

table_items.text: Clinical Electronic Documentation – this is a software system used by Southend Hospital and holds some patient – related documentation.
Care Quality Commission – independent regulator of all health and social care services in England. They ensure that care provided meets national standards of quality and safety.
Collection of facts about people, objects and events, usually collected as the result of experience, observation or experiment, or processes within a computer system
The measure of ‘adequacy' of a record. High quality data is; accurate, up to date, comprehensive, free from duplication, valid, available when needed (timely) and easily read and understood.

Demographic Batch Service – National system which enables a user to submit large numbers of patient records for tracing demographic details against the PDS (Personal Demographics System). It provides back the NHS Number, and up to date demographics where a match can be found.
Human Resources – Department responsible for the recruitment, administration, management and training of staff.

The Department of Health defines this as “the set of standards that the NHS must follow to make sure that it carries out its duty to maintain full and accurate records of the care provided and keep those records confidential, secure and accurate.”
Annual self-assessment of the Trust's position against best practice criteria for information governance set by the Department of Health.
Mid and South Essex University Hospitals Group
NHS Litigation Authority – A not-for-profit part of the NHS. They manage negligence and other claims against the NHS in England on behalf of member organisation.
Open Exeter – this is the local electronic database of NHS patient's demographics details.
Sites Patient Administration Systems / Electronic Patient Record
Payment by Results is transparent, rules based system, which aims to support NHS modernisation by paying Trusts for the work they do and rewarding efficiency and quality.
Personal Demographic Service – this is the national electronic database of the NHS patient demographic details.
Senior Information Risk Officer. Is the Trust's Chief Operating Office. The SIRO acts as an advocate for information risk on the Trust Board and in internal discussions

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities

Information Governance Committee (IGC) is responsible for the review and approval of plans for monitoring and improving data quality and the supervision of compliance with the data quality requirements of the Data Security and Protection Toolkit.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
Chief Executive
Has overall responsibility for ensuring the Group are complete and have valid
data in order to meet legal requirements and national best practice.
Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO)
Executive director nominated by the Board, has overall strategic responsibility for
information risks, including data quality. This entails supporting the delivery of government performance targets and raising the profile of data quality.
Associate Director of Financial Management
Is responsible for ensuring data quality procedural documents are appropriate,
up to date and available when needed. Will chair the Data Quality Committee, ensuring it follows the appropriate reporting procedure.
Data Quality Team
Have responsibility for ensuring data quality procedures are developed and

implemented in like with national best practice and legislative requirements. Will present data quality reports to the Information Governance Committees, in line with their terms of reference; liaise with Trust staff in the development of support, training and guidance as well as co-ordinate and promote data quality initiatives across the Group. The Team are responsible for:
PAS/EPR System Managers/Information Asset Administrators are responsible for:

All Managers are responsible for taking ownership of the data and monitoring the quality of data used within their operational area; ensuring that data quality is regarded as a key priority and arranging training for staff on the use of systems and data collection procedures.
Clinical Coding Team
Healthcare Analytics Team are responsible for:
All Staff
Data Quality Standards
Quality
4.1.1 The staff will ensure that definitions and values entered onto Medway and Lorenzo conform to NHS standards and that local procedures exist to correct identified errors within agreed timescales.

4.1.2 Where practical, validation will take place at the point of data entry, to enable maximum accuracy. On detection of any issues surrounding the quality of data, the relevant staff will be made aware of any changes that are required of them. Measures will be put into operation to make sure that changes to national or local data standards are mirrored in the Group policy and procedures.
Accuracy

4.2.1 Data recorded in patient notes, PAS and other IT systems must reflect precisely what actually took place with the patient. Every available opportunity should be taken to check patient's details with them directly. Inaccurate demographic details within patient records and systems can lead to mis-identification of patients or important correspondence going missing resulting in patient safety incidents.

4.2.2 All reference tables used by electronic systems, such as GPs and postcodes, must be updated regularly. A series of data quality reports have been developed, and will continue to be developed and reviewed, to assist in assuring the accuracy of Group data.

4.2.3 The need for accuracy will be balanced with the importance of the use of the data, and the costs of effort for collection. Where compromises have to be made on the accuracy of data, the limitations will be made clear to the data users.
Validity

4.3.1  All data items held on clinical, business and corporate systems must be valid. Where codes are used these will conform to national standards or map to national values. Where it is practical electronic systems will be set up to accept only valid code entries.
Completeness
4.4.1 Data requirements will be clearly specified based on national standards and the information needs of the organisation. All mandatory data items within a system or data set must be completed.
4.4.2 Default codes will only be used as a last resort, and not as a general replacement for real data.

4.4.3 Procedures are in place to safeguard the completeness and validity of data used internally and externally. These include the requirement to routinely validate information with the relevant source (i.e. with the patient/carer, staff member or using case notes) and undertake any necessary amendments/corrections.
4.4.3  Monitoring of missing, incomplete or invalid data fields will provide an indication of the organisations data quality and indicate any problems in recording certain items.
Timeliness

4.5.1 Clinical data must be captured at the time of activity taking place or as quickly as possible following the event. Staff data must be captured at the point of employment and updated by HR as quickly as possible following notification of changes. This is beneficial for the treatment of patients, management of staff and supports service delivery decisions.
4.5.2 All data must be recorded to deadlines that will qualify it for inclusion in national submissions.
4.5.3 The organisation will undertake to ensure that timescales for national submissions of data are adhered to and that submissions are of the highest standard of quality and accuracy.
Reliability

4.6.1  Data collection processes should be consistent and regular over varying collection points, times and systems. The public, stakeholders and staff should be sure that improvements in performance are due to real changes in practice or processes, rather than variations in data collection methods.
Relevance
4.7.1 Data captured should be relevant to the purposes for which it is being used.

4.7.2 Data captured and the processes for doing so will be subject to periodic review to ensure the organisations changing needs are met. It may be necessary to record data at the point of capture which is relevant for other purposes and not the current use.
Documented Procedures

4.8.1 In order to achieve data quality, good procedures must exist so that staff can be trained and supported in their work. Careful monitoring and error correction can support good quality data, but it is more effective and efficient for data to be entered correctly first time.
4.8.2 Details of these procedures, training sessions and processes are available to all via the public folders on the MSE Intranet.
Identifying and correcting errors
4.9.1 Errors should be identified as close to point of entry as possible. Examples of ways in which this might be done are:
Use of routine information produced by the Healthcare Analytics Department;
Audit trails on Medway / Lorenzo;
Clinical Coding Department reports;
Missing outcomes of attendance reports.
4.9.2 A program of weekly and monthly error reports is produced by the Data Quality Team and Healthcare Analytics.
4.9.3 Investigation of external Data Quality reports, such as SUS, are carried out by the Data Quality Team and Healthcare Analytics.
Measurement of Good Data Quality
Data quality will be subject to control processes within the MSE Group and will also be subject to external scrutiny and audit.

Internal monitoring reports will be discussed at the Data Quality Group meetings and to identify areas where processes can be improved. These will areas will then be added to the Data Quality Action Plan so changes can be implemented and monitored.
External monitoring reports include:
Data Quality reports from SUS;
Queries from Commissioners;
Queries from patient;
Case note audit;
Care Quality Commission inspections rely on information based on sound data and may challenge particular items;
Data Protection and Security Toolkit.
The MSE Group will aim to be significantly above average in all indicators and will strive for 100% accuracy. The organisation will act on all enquiries and complaints from commissioners or patients.
NHS Number

The MSE Group are committed to the continued deployment and use of the NHS Number across systems and processes to meet patient safety and information standards, and protect staff and patient well-being.

The MSE Groups monitor and amend any possible discrepancies against patient records that have caused an error with the National Status of a patient NHS Number (this can effect treatment and payment for the MSB Group).
Systems are put in place for the verification of a patient record against the PDS System for missing NHS numbers and also invalid NHS Numbers.
The Data Quality Team will review these records and amend if necessary.
Any un-matched records returned by the national system will be investigated and resolved, wherever possible.
Data Management

It is vital that all managers with responsibility for staff and systems that collect data, clearly understand data quality standards and requirements fully. In addition, both managers and their staff are committed to making improvements to data quality by acting on any/all data quality reports received.

Support on data management will be provided to staff in the form of system user guidelines which will cover the collection and recording of Person Identifiable Information (PII) e.g. system user guides. In addition, data quality training will be accessed via e-learning and best practice guides will be available to staff through the StaffNet site and the data quality team.
1:1 training and group training relating to Data Quality importance is also available on request.
System guidelines will be reviewed every 2 years or sooner if there are significant system changes, and will be stored on the Trust intranet (StaffNet).
Provision of new services or changes to Group systems must be notified to the system.
All users of systems must be made aware of the impact of any changes in order to maintain the quality of data held.
Data Quality Monitoring
The monitoring and validation of the organisations data will be carried out by the data quality through the following means:
Local and National Benchmarking
Local and national benchmarking will be monitored to identify possible data quality issues, including analysing trends of information over time.
Data Quality Reports
Regular data quality reports and action plans will be presented to the Trust's Information Governance team and Data Quality Committees.
Training
Training and development of staff is fundamental to the achievement of high standards of data quality.
All new staff involved in data collection will receive training in the collection and management of the relevant data and data quality best practice.
All affected staff will receive training prior to any major system implementation, upgrade or replacement.
Staff will not be given access to any electronic system until they have completed training and have been deemed competent.

Formal and informal data quality training and awareness sessions will be available to all staff wishing to attend. These sessions will assist in ensuring staff are familiar with data quality requirements, policies and procedures, providing necessary clarification where required.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and
meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 1)
References
NHS Digital, Systems & Service, Demographics https://digital.nhs.uk/services/demographics

NHS Digital, Data & Information, Looking after information, Data security and information governance https://digital.nhs.uk/data-and-information/looking-after-information/data-security- and-information-governance
The Power of Information: Putting all of us in control of the health and care information we need, Department of Health, 21 May 2012, Gateway Ref: 17668 (The Power of Information)
Risk Management Standards 2013-14, NHS Litigation Authority, March 2013, (NHSLA Standards 2013-14)
Data Protection Act 2018, Crown Copyright (Data Protection Act 2018)
Health and Social Care Act 2012, Health and Social Care Information Centre, http://www.hscic.gov.uk/dq
CQC Fundamental Standards – www.cqc.org.uk
Data Quality Policy / 20212/1.0
Data Quality Policy / 20212/1.0
